body:
Darwin's fox is an endangered canid native to specific places in Chile [\[1\]](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Darwin%27s_Fox_area.png). It's a member of the genus Lycalopex, which makes it more closely related to wolves than true foxes (which are members of the genus Vulpini) [\[2\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/South_American_fox). It's debatable if it even deserves the name, ~~as it has little to do with Charles Darwin~~ [\[3\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Darwin%27s_fox)

In my unprofessional opinion, it is floofy enough to be considered a fox.
body_html:
Darwin's fox is an endangered canid native to specific places in Chile [1]. It's a member of the genus Lycalopex, which makes it more closely related to wolves than true foxes (which are members of the genus Vulpini) [2]. It's debatable if it even deserves the name, as it has little to do with Charles Darwin [3]

In my unprofessional opinion, it is floofy enough to be considered a fox.
